div.p: ¶ ANNO PRIMO EDVVARDI SEXTI.

¶ STATVTES made in the Parliament begon at westminster the fower the daye of Nouember, in the first yeare of the reigne of the most dreade Soueraine lord EDWARD the .VI. By the grace of God, Kinge of Englande, Fraunce, and Irelande, defendour of the faith, and of the Churche of Englande, and also of Ireland in earthe the supreme hed and from theme continued to the xxiiii. daye of Decembre then next ensuyng, that is to say in the first Session of the same Parliament, as foloweth.

div.head: ¶ An Acte against suche persons as shall vnreuerentlye speake against the Sacrament of the body and bloud of Christe, commonly called the Sacrament of the Aulter: & for the receiuyng therof vnder both kindes. ¶ The first Chapiter.
div.p:
THE Kinges moste excellent Maiesty minding the gouernaunce & order of his most louing subiects to be in moste perfite vnitie and concord, in al thinges, & in especial, in the true faith & Religion of God, & wishinge the same to be brought to passe with all clemency and mercy, on his highnesse parte towardes them, as his moste Princely serenity & Maiestye hath alreadye declared by euident proufe to thintent that hys most louing subiects prouoked by clemency & goodnesse of their Prince & kyng, shall studye rather for loue, thē for feare to doe theire duties, first to almighty God, & then to his highnesse & the common wealth, nourishyng concord & loue emong them selues: yet cōsidereth & perceyueth that in a multitude al bee not on that sort, that reason and the knowledge of their duityes cā moue them from offence, but many, which had neede haue some bridle of feare, & that the same be men moste contencious & arrogante for the moste parte, or elles most blinde & ignoraunt: by the meanes of whych sort of men, many things well & godlye instituted, & to the dificacion of many, be peruerted & abused, & turned to their own & others gret losse & hinderaunce, & some time to extreme destruccion: the which doth appeare in nothing more or soner, then in matters of Religion, and in the great & high misteries therof, as in the moste comfortable Sacrament of the body & bloud of our sauiour Iesus Christe, commonly called the Sacramente of the Aulter, and in scripture, thei. Cor. 11. Supper andi. Cor. 8 Table of the Lord, thei. Cor. 10. Communioni. Cor. 10. and partaking of the body and bloud of Christe: which Sacrament was instituted of no lesse aucthor, then of our Sauiour, both God & man, when at his last supper emongst his Apostles he did take ye bread into his holy hands, & did sayMath. 26. Take you & eate, this is my body, which is Luke. 22 geuen & i. Cor. 11 broken for you. And taking vp ye Math. 26. Marke. 14. chalice or cup, didMarke. 14 geue thāks & say, This is my bloud of the newe testamēt, which is shed for you Luke. 21 & for Marke. 14 many, for the remission of sinnes, yt i. Cor. 11 whensoeuer we should do ye same, we should do it in ye remēbrāce of him, & to declare & set forth his death & most glorious passiō, vntil his cōming. Of ye whichMath. 26 bread, whosoeuer eateth, or of ye which cup whosoeuer drynketh vnworthely, eateth & drinketh condēpnacion & iudgement to him selfe, making no difference of the Lordes body.i. Cor. 11 The institucion of which Sacramente being ordeyned by Chryste,i. Cor. 11. as is before said, and the saide woordes spoken of it here before rehearsed, being of eternal, infallible, & vndoubted trueth: yet the said Sacramēt (al this notwithstanding) hath been of late merueilously abused by suche maner
of men before rehearsed, who of wickednesse, or els of ignoraunce & want of learning for certein abuses, heretofore, committed of some, in misusing therof, haue condempned in their hartes and speche, ye whole thing, and contempteously depraued, despised, or reuiled the same most holy and blessed Sacrament, and not onely disputed & reasoned vnreuerently and vngodly of that most high misterye, but also in theire sermons: preachinges, readinges, lectures, communicacions, arguments, talkes, runes, songes, plaies, or gestes, name, or call it by suche vile and vnsemely woordes, as Christian eares doe abhorre to heare rehersed: for reformacion whereof be it enacted by the Kings highnesse with the assent of the Lordes spirytual and temporall, & of the commons in this present Parliament assembled, and by the aucthority of the same, that whatsoeuer persone or persons, from, and after the first daye of Maye next comming, shall depraue, despise or contemne the saide most blessed Sacrament, in contempt thereof by any contempteous woords, or by any wordes of deprauing, despising, or reuiling: or what person, or persons, shal aduisedsy in any otherwise contemne, despise, or reuile ye saide most blessed Sacrament, contrary to the effectes, & declaracion aboue saide, that then he, or they, shall suffer imprisonment, of his, or their bodies & make fine & raunsome at the kinges wil & pleasure.

And for full and effectual execucion of the premisses before deuysed, ordeined and enacted by this act: be it furthermore enacted by the aucthoritie of this present Parliament, that immediatly after the first day of May next comming, the Iustices of peace, or three of them at ye least wherof one of them to be of the Quorum, in euery shire of this Realme and Wales, and al other places within the kings dominions, shal haue ful power and aucthoritie by vertue of this act, aswel to take informacion and accusacion by thothes and deposicions of twoe able, honest, & leful persons at the least, and after suche accusacion, or informacion so had to enquire by the othes of .xii. men, in euery their .iiii. quarter sessyons yerely to be holden, of al and singuler such accusacions, or informacions to be had, or made of any of the offences abouesaid, to be committed, or done after the saide first day of May, within the limits of theire commission: and that vpon euery such accusacion and informacion, the offendour, and offendours shalbe inquired of, & indicted before the said Iustices of peace, or three of thē at ye least, as is aforesaid, of the said cōtemptes and offences, by the verdict of .xii. honest, and indifferent men if the matter of the said accusacion & informacion shal seme to the saide Iury good and true.

And it is also further enacted by the aucthoritie aforesaide, that the saide Iustices of peace, or three of them at the least, as is aforesaid, before whom any suche presentment, informacion, and accusacion shall be made, or taken, as is aforesaide, shall examine the accusors, what other witnesse were by, and present at the time of the doing and committing
of thoffence: wherof the informacion, accusacion, & presentment shalbe made, and how many others then the accusors, haue knowledge therof: and shal haue power and aucthoritie, by their diserecions, to bind by recognisaunce to be taken before them aswell the said accusours, as all suche other persones, whom the same accusoures shall declare to haue knowlege of the offences by them presented & informed euery of them in fiue poundes to the king, to appeare before ye said Iustices of peace before whom the offendour, or offendors shalbe tried at the day of trial and delyuerance of suche offendours.

And it is further enacted by the aucthoritie aforesayd, that the sayd Iustices of Peace, or three of them at the least, as is abouesaid, by vertue of this acte, shall haue full power and aucthorytie to make processe agaynste euerye persone & persones so indicted by two Capias & an exigent, and by Capias vtlagat{ur}, aswell within the lymyttes of their cōmission, as into al other Shieres & places of this realme, Wales, and other the Kinges dominions, aswel wythin the libertyes as withoute, & the same processe to be good and effectual in the law to al intents, constructions and purposes, & vppon the apparaunce of any of the offendours, shall haue full power & aucthoritye by vertue of this acte, and the commissyon of peace, to determyne the contemptes and offences aforesaid, accordyng to the lawes of this Realme, and effectes of thys acte: and that the said Iustices of peace, or three of them at the least, as is aboue sayd, shall haue full power and aucthoritye to let anye suche persone, or persones so indicted, vppon suffycyent suerties, by their discrecions, to baile, for their apparaunce to be tried, according to the tenour, fourme, & effect of thys acte.

Prouided alwaies, and be it enacted, that the said Iustices of peace or three of them at the least, at their quarter Sessions, where any offēdour or offendours shalbe, or stande indicted of any of the contemptes, or offences abouesaide, shall directe & awarde one write in the kinges name to the Bishop of the Diocese, wherin the sayde offence or offēces are supposed to be committed, or done willynge and requiring the said Bishop to be in his owne persone, or by his Chauncellour, or other his suffycient deputye learned, at the quarter Sessions in the said County to ve holden when, & where the saide offendour shalbee arreigned and tried, appointing to them in the sayd writ the day and place of the sayd arraignement, whiche write shalbe of this fourme: Rex &c. Ep̄o L. Salutem. Praecipimus tibi, quod tu, Cancellarius tuus, vel alius Deputatus tuus sufficient{ur} eruditus, sitis cum Iusticiarijs nostris ad pacem in com̄ nr̄o B. conseruand assignat{ur} apud D. tali die, ad Sessionem nostram, ad tunc & ibm̄ tenend' and dand' consiliū & aduisament' eisdem Iusticiarijs nostris ad pacē super arrainment & deliberationem offendent' contra formā statuti, cōcernen̄ sacro sanctum Sacramentum Altatis.

Prouided alwaies, and bee it enacted by the aucthority abouesaide
that no persone or persones shalbe indicted of any of the contempts, or offences abouesayd, but onely of such contempts, or offences, as shal be doone, or perpetrated within three monethes, next after the said offences, or offence so committed or done.

And be it further enacted by the aucthority aforesaide, that in al trialles for any suche offendours before the saide Iustices, as is aforesaid the persone or persones being complaind on and arraigned, shall be admitted to purge or trie his, or their innocencie, by as many, or moe witnesses in number & of as good honestye and credence, as the witnesses be, whiche deposed against him, or any of them.

And for asmuche as it is more agreable, both to the first instytucyon of the saide Sacrament, of the moste precious bodye and bloud of our Sauiour Iesus Christ, and also more conformable to the common vse and practise both of the Apostles, and of the primatiue Churche, by the space of fiue hundreth yeres, and more, after Christs ascention, that the saide blessed Sacrament should be ministred to al Christyan people vnder bothe the kyndes of bread & wine, then vnder the fourme of bread onely: and also it is more agreable to the first institucion of Christ, and to the vsage of the Apostles, and the primatiue church, that the people being present should receiue the same with the Priest, then yt the Priest should receiue it alone: therfore be it enacted by our Soueraine Lorde the Kyng with the consent of the lordes Spirytuall & Temporall, and the commons in thys present Parlyamente assembled, and by the aucthority of the same, that the saide moste blessed Sacrament be hereafter cōmonly deliuered, & ministred vnto the people, within this churche of England and Ireland, & other the Kinges dominyons vnder bothe the kynds, that is to say, of bread and wine, except necessitie otherwise require: and also that the Priest, whiche shall minister the same, shall at the least one day before exhort al persones, whiche shalbe present, lykewise to resorte and prepare themselues to receiue the same. And when the day prefixed cometh, after a godly exhortaciō by the minister made (wherein shalbe further expressed the benefite and comforte promysed to them, whiche worthely receiue the holye Sacrament, and daunger and indignacion of God threatned to them, whiche shall presume to receiue the same vnworthely, to the ende that euery manne may trie and examine his owne conscience before he shal receiue the same) the sayde minister shal not without a lawful cause denie the same to any persone, that wil deuoutly and humbly desire it: any lawe, statute, ordinaunce, or custome contrary thereunto in any wise notwithstandinge, not condempning hereby the vsage of any churche oute of the kynges Maiesties dominions.

div.head:
¶ An Acte for the election of Bishoppes, and what Seales and stile they, and other Spiritual persons exercising iurisdiccion Ecclesiastical shal vse.
¶ The .ii. Chapiter.
div.p: FOrasmuche as the eleccyon of the Archebyshoppes and Bysshoppes by the Deanes and Chapiters, within the Kynges Maiesties Realmes of Englande and Irelande, at thys present tyme, be aswell to the longe delaye, as to the great costes and charges of suche persons, as the Kings Maiestie geueth any Archebishoprich, or Bishopriche vnto: and whereas the sayde elections be in very deede no elections, but onely by a writte of Conge deslier, haue coloures, shadowes or pretences of elections, seruinge neuerthelesse to no purpose, & seming also derogatorye and preiudicial to the kynges prerogatiue roial, to whom onelye apperteinethe the collacyon and gifte of all Archebishopriches, and Bishopriches, and Suffragain Bishoppes, within his highnesse saide Realmes of England, and Ireland, Wales, and other his dominions and Marches: For a due reformacion hereof, be it therefore enacted by the Kinges highnes with the assent of the Lordes Spirituall and Temporall, and the Commons in this present Parliament assembled, and by aucthoritie of the same, that from henceforth, no such Conge deslier be graunted, nor election of any Archebyshoppe or Bishoppe, by the Deane and Chapiter made: But that the kyng may by his letters Patents at al times, when any Archbishopriche, or Bishopriche be voide, conferre the same to anye persone whom the king shall thinke meete. The whiche collacion so by the kinges letters Patentes made, and deliuered to the person, to whom the king shall conferre the same Archebishoprich or Bishopriche, or to hys sufficient Proctour, and Attourney, shall stande to al intents, constructions and purposes, to asmuche and the same effecte, as though Conge deslier had ben geuen, the election duely made, and the same cōfirmed: and that vpon the saide persone, to whom the sayde Archebishoprich, Bishoprich, or Suffraganshippe is so conferred, collated, or geuen, may be consecrated, and sue his liuerie, or ouster le maine, and do other thinges aswell, as if the saide ceremonies and elections had beene doone & made.

Prouyded alwayes, and be it enacted by aucthoritie aforesaid, that euery suche persone, to whom any collacion, or gift of any Archebishopriche, Bishopriche, or Suffraganshippe shalbe geuen or collated by the king, his heires, or successours, shal pay, doe, and yelde to all and euery persone, all suche fees, interestes, and duties, as of olde time haue been accustomed to bee done: any thing in this act, or in any other, to the cōtrary hereof, in any wise notwithstanding.

And where as the Archebishoppes and Bishoppes, and other Spyritual persons in this Realme dooe vse to make & sende out their sommons, citacions, and other processe in theire owne names, and in suche fourme and maner, as was vsed in the tyme of the vsurped power of ye Bishop of Rome, contrary to the fourme and order of the sommōs and
processe of the common lawe vsed in this realme: seeing that al aucthoritie of Iurisdiccion, Spiritual and temporal, is deriued and deducted from the Kinges Maiestie, as supreme head of these Churches & Realmes of Englande, and Ireland, and so iustly acknowleged by the clergie of the saide Realmes, & that al courts ecclesiasticall, within the said twoe Realmes bee kepte by noe other power, or aucthoritie eyther foreyne, or wythin the Realme, but by the aucthorytie of hys moste excellent Maiestie: Bee it therefore further enacted by the aucthoritie aforesaid, that al somons & citacions, or other processe ecclesiastical, in al suites and causes of instaunce, betwixt partie & party, and all causes of correction, and al causes of bastardie, or begamie, or inquirie de Iure Patronatus, probates of testamentes, and commissions of administraciō of persones deceassed, and all acquitaunces, of, and vppon accomptes made by the executours, administratrours, or collectours of goods of any ded persone, be from the firste day of Iuly nexte folowing made in the name, and with the stile of the king, as it is in writtes origynall, or iudicial at the common lawe: and that the teste therof be in the name of ye Archbishop or Bishop, or other hauing Ecclesiastical iurisdiccion who hath the commission and graunt of the aucthority Ecclesiastical, immediatly from the Kinges highnesse, and that his commissary, officiall, or substitute exercising iurisdiccion vnder him, shal put his name in the citacion, or processe after the teste.

Furthermore, be it enacted by aucthoritie aforesaide, that all maner of person or persons, who hath the exercise of Ecclesiasticall iurisdicciō shall haue from the first day of Iuly before expressed, in theire seales of Office, the Kinges highnesse armes decently sette with certain carects vnder the armes, for the knowledge of the Diocese: and shal vse no other seale of iurisdiccion, but wherin his Maiesties armes be engrauē vppon pein that if any person shall vse Ecclesiastical iurisdiccyon (after the day before expressed) in this Realme of England, wales, and other his dominions, or territories, and not sende, or make out the Citacion, or processe in the kyngs name, or vse any seale of iurisdiccion, other thē before limitted that euery suche offendoure shall incurre, & runne in the Kinges Maiesties displeasure, & indignacion, and suffre imprisonment at his highnesse will & pleasure.
Prouided alwaies, that no more, nor other fees be taken, or paid for the Seale & writting of any Citacions, or other processe, thē was here tofore accustomed.

Prouided also, and bee it enacted by the aucthoritie aforesaid, that the Archebishoppe of Cantorbury for the time being, shal vse his owne seale, and in his owne name, in al faculties and dispensacion, according to the tenour of an acte therof made: and that the sayde Archebishops and Bishoppes shall make, admitte, order, and refourme their Chauncellours, Officialles, Commissaries, Aduocates, Proctours, and other
their offycers, ministers, & substitutes, & commissyons to Suffragaine Bishoppes in their owne names, vnder their own seales, in such maner & fourme, as they haue heretofore vsed: & shal certify to the Courte of Tenthes, their certificats vnder their owne names & seales, as heretofore they haue vsed, & accordinge to the statute in that case made & prouyded: & likewise shall make collacions, presentacions, giftes, institucions, & inductions of benefites, letters or orders, or dimissories, vnder their owne names & seales, as they haue heretofore accustomed: anye thing in this act conteyned to the contrary notwithstanding.

Prouided alwaies, & be it enacted by the aucthoritie aforesaid, that al processe hereafter to be made, or awarded by any Ecclesiastical person or persons, for the triall of any plea, or pleas, or matter depending, or that hereafter shal depend in any of the kings courts of Recorde, at the common lawe, & limitted by the lawes & customes of this realme, to the spiritual courtes to trie the same: that the certificat of the same, after the trial therof shalbe made in the kings name, for the time being and with the stile of rhe same kyng, and vnder the seale of the Bishop, grauen with the kings armes, with the name of the Bishop, or spirituall officer beinge to the teste of the same processe and certificat, and to euery of them.

div.head: ¶ The .iii. Chapiter. ¶ An acte for the punishing of vagaboundes, & for the relief of the poore and impotent persons.
div.p:
FOrasmuche, as idlenesse and vagabondry, is the mother and roote of all theftes, robberyes, and all euill actes, and other mischiefes, and the multitude of people geuen thereto hathe alwaies bene here within this Realme very great, and more in number (as it maye appeare) then in other Regions, to the great impouerishment of the Realme, and daunger of the kings highnesse subiectes: the which idlenesse & vagaboundry al the kyngs highnesse noble progenitours, kinges of this realme, and thys high courte of parliament hath often and with great trauaile, gon about & assayed with godly actes & statutes, to represse, yet vntill this our time, it hath not had that successe, which hath bene wished, but partly by folishe pytie and mercy of them, which should haue sene the saide godly laws executed, partly by the peruerse nature, and long accustomed idlenes of the persons geuen to loitering, the saide godly statutes hetherto hathe had small effecte, and idle and vagabonde persons, being vnprofitable members, or rather enemies of the common wealth, hath bene suffered to remain and increase, and yet so do whom, if they should be punished by death, whipping, imprisonmente, and with other corporal paine, it were not without their desertes for the example of others, and to the benefite of the cōmon wealth: yet if they could be brought to be made profitable, and doe seruyce, it were muche to bee wished and desired:
Be it therefore enacted by the kynges highnes, with the consent of the Lordes Spiritual & temporal, & the commons in this present Parlyament assembled, & by aucthoritie of the same, first that all statutes and actes of parliament heretofore made for the punishment of vagabonds & sturdy beggers, & all articles comprised in the same, shalbe frō henceforth repealed, voide & of none effect.

Secondly, that whosoeuer, after the first daye of Aprill nexte following, man, or woman being not lame, impotent, or so aged, or diseased with sicknesse, that he, or she cannot woorke, not hauing lands, or tenementes, fees, annuities, or any other yerely reuenues, or profits where on they may finde sufficiently their liuing, shal, eyther like a seruing mā wanting a Master, or like a begger, or after anye suche other sorte, bee lurking in any house, or houses, or loytering, or idly wander by ye highwaies side, or in stretes, in cities, townes, or villages, not applying thē selfe to some honest, and allowed arte, science, seruice, or labour, and so do continue by the space of three daies, or more together, and not offer them selues to labour with any that wil take them, according to theire faculty: & if no man, otherwise will take them, do not offre themselues to woorke for meate and drinke, or after they be so taken to worke, for the space agreed betwixt them & their master, doe leaue theire woorke out of conuenient time, or run away: that then euery such persone shall be taken for a vagabounde, and that it shalbe lawful to euery such master offring such idle persone seruice, and labour, and that being by him refused, or who hathe agreed wyth suche idle persone, and from whom within the space agreed of seruice, the said loyterer hath rūne away, or departed before the end of the couenaunt betwene them, and to any other person espying the same to bring, or cause to be brought the sayde persone so liuing idly, and loyteringly, to two of the nexte Iustices of ye Peace there resiaunt, or abiding, who hearing the proufe of the idle lyuynge of the said persone by the saide space liuing idly, as is aforesaid, approued to them by two honest witnesses, or confession of the partye, shall immediatly cause the saide loiterer to be marked with an hoat Iron in the breast, the marke of V. and adiudge the saide persone liuinge so idly to suche presentour, to be his slaue: to haue and to holde the said slaue to him, his executours, or assignes for the space of two yeres then next folowing, and to order the saide slaue, as foloweth: that is to say to take suche persone adiudged a slaue with him, and onely geuing the saide slaue bread and water, or small drinke, and such refuse of meat as he shal thinke mete, cause the saide slaue to woorke by beatinge, cheyning, or otherwise, in suche woorke and labour (how vile soeuer it be) as he shall put him vnto. And if any maner of slaue, eyther for loitering or for the cause before rehersed so adiuged, shal within the space of the sayde two yeares here appointed runne awaye, departe, or absente him from his said master, by the space of .xiiii. daies together, without
licence: It shal not onely be lefull to his said Maister to pursue & serch him again by vertue of this acte, but also to punishe such fault by cheynes, or beating, as is aforesaide: and against the deteinour, if any man doe wyllynglye deteine him, knowing him to be a slaue, as is aforesaid to haue an action of trespasse, and recouer thereby in damages tenne poundes, besides the costs and charges of the suite for so deteyning his saide slaue. And further, euery such master shewing, & prouyng by two suffycient witnesses, the saide offence and faulte of hys runnyng away before twoe Iustices of Peace of the same Countye, whereof the one to be of the Quorum, the same Iustyces shal cause suche slaue, or loyterer to be marked on the forehed, or the balle of the cheke with an hoate Iron, with the signe of an S. that he may be knowen for a loyterer, and a runne awaye, and shal adiuge the loyterer, and runne away to be the saide Masters slaue for euer. And if suche slaue shall the seconde tyme runne away, or absent him selfe. if the saide Master shall approue the same seconde runnyng awaye, with twoe sufficient witnesses before ye Iustice of peace, in their general and quarter sessyons: then euery suche faulte and running away to be adiudged felony, and such loytererer & runne away to be taken as a felon, and therof being lawfully indicted and attainted, or otherwise condempned to suffer peines of deathe, as other felons ought to doe.

Prouided also, and bee it enacted by aucthoritie aforesaide, that no clerke conuicted shall hereafter make his purgacion, & vppon such purgacion be deliuered, and set at large otherwise then is in the Statute hereafter expressed.

And be it further enacted by auctoritie aforesaide that euerye clerke conuict, or hereafter to be conuicted, whych should by the order of the lawe enioye the benefite of their purgacion, shall and may from henceforth finde any man (if they can) who shall be bound with two suffycyent suerties to the ordinary, in the summe of .xx. li. to the kings highnes vse, to retaine the said conuict as his slaue, and, to kepe the sayd person so conuicte for the space of one yere then next folowing, that he shal not goe abroade, and at large, and then the said conuicte shal bee deliuered to the saide persone so taking the same, & being bound, as is aforesaid, to be his slaue for one whole yere then next folowing by vertue of this acte, in all such maner and fourme, and to all suche intentes and purposes, and with all such order lawes, condicions, & penalties for • iuining away, or other, as is aforesaid of a vagabonde, taken loitering & made a slaue (burning in the breast onely except:) & the ordinarye by the deliuery of the saide conuicte to such person being bound, as is aforesaid to be of the keping of the saide conuict clerely discharged, and exonerated by vertue of this acte.

And if so be that the saide clerke so conuicte cannot finde anye man to be bounde, as is aforesaide, to whom he may be adiudged a slaue in
the space of one yere: then at any time after thend of one yere, after his conuiction, it shalbe lawful for the said Clerke conuict to make his purgacion, as he might before this estatute, any thing in this presente acte to the contrary notwithstandyng.

And where the Clarkes conuicted, or atteynted by the order of the lawes of thys Realme, cannot make their purgacion, and should perpetually by the same remayne in prison, bee it neuerthelesse enacted by the aucthoritie aforesaide, that if there be any maner of person, who wil at any time demaund the same clerke conuicted, or attaynted, & be bound to the ordinary with two sufficient suerties, as is aboue writtē, to kepe the same as his slaue, by the space of fiue yeres then next folowing, that then the same shalbe adiudged his slaue for like space, with al such orders, lawes, and penalties, for running awaye, and other orders, as is before expressed of a vacabounde adiudged to any man for a slaue (the burning in the breast onely except) &. vpon the adiudgement deliuered to suche demaundaunt, thordinarye from thenceforth of the keping of such Clerke conuicted, or attainted, clerely exonerated, and discharged by vertue of this acte.

And forasmuch as diuers women and men goeth on begging wayfairing, of the which some be impotent and lame, and some able enough to labour, whiche doe carye children about with them, some .iiii. or .v. yeres of age, or yonger, or elder, whiche brought vp in idlenesse might be so roted in it, that hardely they may be brought after to good thrifte and labor: or if any childe aboue the age of fiue yeres, & vnder the age of .xiiii. yeres go idlye wandring about as a vagabonde: be it enacted by the aucthoritie aforesaide, that if any maner of person will take any such childe, bee it male, or female, of, and from any suche begger beinge the mother therof, nourisher or keper, whether they bee willing or not, or without any suche norice, mother or keper by him selfe wandering, and bring the saide childe so taken away before one of the Constables of the parishe, and two other honeste, and discrete neighbors witnesses, and before any Iustice of peace there resiaunt, and abydinge, and promesse to bring the same childe vp in some honest labor, or occupaciō til he or she come to the age of .xx. yeres the woman childe. or .xxiiii. the man childe: that then and immediatly the saide Iustice of Peace & Cōstable shal adiudge by vertue of this acte, the said child vnto the ages before specified, to be seruauntes or apprentices to the saide persons so taking and promising to be vsed and ordered in all pointes accordinge as the lawe and custome of this Realme is of seruauntes and apprentices, to what labour occupation, or seruice soeuer the saide Master shal appointe him, or her, during the saide time. And if it shall fortune suche childe so adiudged to runne away at any time, once, or moe times, from his or her master, or mastres: that then it shalbe lawful for euery suche Maister, to take the saide childe again, and to kepe and punish the said
chylde, in cheynes or otherwise, and vse him, or her, as hys slaue in all pointes, for the tyme before rehearsed, of the age of suche chylde, that is to say, till twentie the woman childe, and the man childe .xxiiii.

Prouided alwayes, that any maister, eyther of the men, or of the women so adiudged slaues, or of the children adiudged apprentices or seruauntes, may lette, set forth, sel, bequeathe, or geue the seruice & labor of suche slaues or seruauntes so adiudged, as is aforesayde, to any persone, or persones, to whomsoeuer he will, vpon suche condition, and for suche tyme of yeres as the saide persones bee adiudged to him for slaues, seruauntes, or apprentices, after suche like sorte and maner, as he may do of any other his moueable goodes or cattalles: and they for the said space and time, to be bound to all poinctes and constructions to such lessee, donee, vendee, or assignee, as they were to theire first apprehenders and maisters, by vertue of this statute.

Prouided alwayes, & bee it enacted by aucthoritie aforesayde: that if any such slaue, or slaues, or children so adiudged, shall at any tyme after suche adiudgement, mayme, or wounde theire maisters or mistresses, in resisting theire correction, or otherwise: or when they be Manumitted, & set agayne free, or in the tyme of their seruice, shall conspire with anye other, or by themselues go about to murder & kyl, or to maime, wounde, or beate the said maister or maistresse, or any that was theire maister or maistresse, or to burne their houses, barnes, or corne, so that their entent come to an acte tending to the effecte: that then euerye suche maime, or wounde, or the going about to murder, kill, maime, wounde, or beate suche persone or persones, as bee, or were theire maister or mistressesses, or to burne their houses, barnes, or corne, so that their entent do come to any acte tending to the same effecte, as lying in wayte with weapon, or anye suche like, shalbe accompted Felonye, and they shal suffer therefore peines of death, as in case of Felonie: excepte that anye suche persone or persones as be, or had been maister or maistresse to any of them, or he refusing any other wil take suche person so offending, to theire slaues, and thē he or she so offending to be adiudged to the person so willing to take him or her so offending slaue for euer, and therupon to be discharged of the felonie. The same lawe and ordre to be had in all cōditiōs, if it should chaūce the father, mother, nourice, or other the bearer about of the child or any other persone, or persones, to steale away suche childe adiudged apprentice or seruaunt, that is, to bee slaue to suche apprentices, or seruauntes maister, whose apprentice or seruaunt was so stolen or entised awaie, for euer: & the maister neuertheles to take & receiue his said apprētice or seruaūt again, as if the said taking awaie had neuer be doen.

Bee it also enacted by aucthoritie aforesaid, that although there be no man which shall demaūde such loiterer, or loiterers, as before expressed into theire seruice, yet neuerthelesse the Iustice of peace in that citie, boroughe, towne, or hundred dwelling, if anye suche bee, or els anye other
Iustice of peace of the same Shyre, and also there dwellinge, by hys, or theire office shalbe hereafter bounde by vertue of thys acte, not onely to enquire of all suche ydle persones, but also if they doe espye anye suche vagabondes, or ydle persone, or if anye suche bee detected vnto them, to examine him, or her, of the tyme of theyr vagaboundrye: and if it shall appeare to any Iustice of peace, any suche man or woman to haue been a vagraunt and vagabound, or ydle person, by the space as is aforesaid, to cause the same to bee marked on the breste with an. V. made with an hoate yron, and also to learne and enquire of hym the Towne, Citie, or village, wherein hee was borne, and then shall immediately geue a writing in parchement sealed with hys seale, to the sayd loyterer, of the tenour & fourme, which here ensueth. ¶ A.B. Iustice of peace in the coūtie of S. to the Maiour, or chiefe officer of the citie of. Q. (if it be a Citye, or to the head borough, Baylife, or Constable, or head officer of the towne of Q. (if it bee a Towne) or to the Constable, or Tything man of the Village of C. (if it be a village) greting: According to a moste, godlye Statute made in the first yere of the reigne of our Souereigne Lorde kyng Edwarde the sixte &c. we haue taken thys bearer. I.K., vagrauntlye, and to the euill example of others, without maister, seruice, or labor whereby to gette hys liuing, going loitering idlye aboute. And because the same sayth, he was borne in C. in the countie of S. wherof you are the head officer or Constable. We haue sent hym to you to be ordred according to the purporte and effect of the same Statute. And with thys writing shall deliuer the same loyterer to the Constables, or other head officer of the said Citie, Towne, or Village, wherein suche loyterer was taken, to be safely conueighed by them to the nexte Constable, & so from Constable to Constables, & other head officers, till he or she be brought to the place, the whiche, he or she, hath named them selfe to bee borne in, and then to bee deliuered to the heade officer or Constable of that same Citie, Borough, or Towne, Village, Hamlette, or Paryshe, there to bee nourished and kept of the same Citie. Towne, or Village, in cheynes, or otherwise, either at the common workes, in amending hyghe wayes, or other common worke, or from man to man in order, till they which may beare be equally charged to be slaue to the corporation of the citie, or to the inhabitauntes of the towne or village, that he or she were borne in, after all suche fourme, condition, space of yeres, ordres, punishments for running away, & all others, as are expressed of a commō or priuate persone to whom any such loiterer is adiudged a slaue. And the sayde citie, Towne, or village shall see the sayde slaue beyng able to labour, sette on worke, & not liue idlye within the said precinctes, vpon paine for euerye suche defaulte, that the sayde slaue doth lyue ydly, by the defaulte of the Citie, borough, or towne, or village, by the space of thre working dayes together, the citie of forfeite .v. li. a Borough, or towne incorporate xl. s. and other towne or village .xx.s. whereof the one halfe to the kyng our
soueraigne lord, the other to him that will sue for the same, in any of the kynges courtes of Record, by bill, information, or action of debte, in the which suites, no essoine, wager of lawe, or protection shalbe allowed.

Prouided and be it enacted, that the Citie, Towne, and borough corporate, by the consent of the more parte of the corporation: & the towne and village not corporate, by the consent of the more parte of the inhabitauntes thereof, may sette, sell, or geue awaye the righte, title, & interest of the saide slaue, to anye other person, as any other common or priuate persone may do with hys slaue, by the vertue of thys Acte.

Prouided alwayes, and be it enacted, that if it fortune when the saide vacabonde is brought to the sayde Citie, Towne, or village, where the said persone said he was borne, to appeare, & be manifest, that he, or shee was not there borne: that then for suche lye, the saide vagaraunt shalbe marked in the face with an. S. and be slaue to the inhabitauntes, or corporation of the Citie, Towne, or village, where the saide vagaraunte sayde he was borne in, for euer, vpon such conditions, and orders, in all poynctes, as of a slaue marked in the face is before expressed: the same lawe, and order in all poinctes to be had of all vagaraunt persones, and vagabondes beinge borne in anye other nation or countreye, then thys Realme, as is before expressed of Englishe ydle persones, (markinge in the breast or face onely excepted) that is, to be had to the next porte, and there to be kepte of the inhabitauntes of the sayde nexte port, in conuenient labour, and from ydlenesse, or otherwise, till they may be conueyed ouer: and then at the costes of the inhabitauntes of the sayd porte, to be conueighed ouer into their countreyes.

And forasmuche as there is manye maymed, & otherwise lamed, sore aged, & impotent persones, which resorteth to the citie of London, & to other cities, townes, & villages, on begging: whose coming together, & makinge a number, doth fill the streetes or high wayes of diuers cities, townes, markettes & fayres, who, if they wer seperated, mought easely be nourished in the townes & places wherin they were borne, or where they were, or haue been most conuersaunt and abidinge, by the space of three yeres: Be it therfore enacted by the aucthoritie aforesaide, that all & singuler Mayours, Shirifes, Baylifes, Constables, or other head officers of any citie, towne, or hundred, to whiche suche resorte is, or shalbe, shal before the feast of the Purification of our Lady next folowing, see all such ydle, impotent, maymed, & aged persones, who otherwise can not by their discretions bee taken for vagabondes, whiche were borne within the said citie, towne, or Hundrede, or hath been there moste conuersaunt and abiding by the space of three yeres as is aforesaid, & now decayed, bestowed, and prouided for of Tenantries, Cotages, or other conuenient houses, to bee lodged in, at the costes & charges of the sayde Cities, townes, boroughes, and villages, there to be releued and cured by the deuotion of the good people of the said Citie, borough, towne, or
village. And that they doe not suffer after the time before rehersed, any other then suche as eyther were borne, or hathe been for the most parte conuersaunt or abiding, by the space aforesayde, in the sayde Citie, Boroughe, Village, or Towne, to remaine and begge abroade within the precinctes of such Cities, Townes, villages, or Hundredes: vpon peine that euerye such Maiours, Shirifes, and Baylifes, Constable, or other head officer, by what name so euer he be called suffering any persones to begge within the precincte of hys or theire suche iurisdiction, other then is before rehearsed, for euery three dayes shal forfait x.s. to whomsoeuer will sue therfore, by byll, information, or action of debte, in anye Courte of Recorde, in the whiche suites, no essoyne, wager of lawe, nor protection shalbe allowed.

And for the better perfourmance hereof: be it enacted by aucthoritie aforesayd, that the Maiour of the Citie of London, and all othor Maiours, Baylifes, Shirifes, Constables, and other head officers of euery citie, and towne corporate, doe with al conuenient spede by themselfes, or theire sufficient deputies by them appoincted, before the feaste of the Purification next comming, and so from tyme to tyme, euery Moneth once, make a view and examination of aged, impotent, and lame {per}sōs, beggers, as be within the precincte of their iurisdiction, and see all such as were not borne, nor hath been for the moste parte conuersaunt and abyding there by the space for three yeares complete, conueyed on horsebacke, carte, or chariotte, or otherwise, as shall seeme by theire discretions, to the next Constables, and they to conueigh the same to the next Cōstables, & so from Constables to Constables, till the sayd persons be brought to the place where they were borne, or most conuersaunt and abiding, as is aforesayde, there to be prouided for, kepte, and nourished of almose, as is aforesayde: vpon the paine that euerye suche Mayour, Shirife, or Constable, head borough, or head officer not making viewe not sending or conueyghing awaye, not receiuing, or not prouiding, as is before appointed, according to the true purport or meaninge of thys acte, to forfeyte for euerye suche defaulte xl.s. Whereof the one halfe to the kynges vse, the other to the partie that will sue therefore in anye of the kynges courts of Recorde, by bill, information, action of debt, in the which suites, none essoine, wager of law, nor protectiō shalbe allowed.

Prouided alwayes, that yf any of the sayde aged, maymed, or impotēt persones of the Cities, townes, or villages where they were borne in, or had their most abiding, as is aforesayde, be not so lame or impotent, but that they may worke in some maner of worke: that then suche citie, Towne, Parishe, or Village, doe eyther in common prouide some suche worke for them, as they may bee occupied in, or appointe them to suche as will finde them woorke for meate and drinke. And yf theye refuse of wilfulnesse and stubburnesse to worke, or doe runne away, and begge in other places, then to punishe the same according to theire discretions,
with cheyning, beating, or otherwise, as shal seeme to them conuenient. And for the more furtheraunce of the reliefe of suche whiche are in vnfained misery, and to whom charitie ought to be extended: be it enacted by aucthoritie aforesayde, that euery Sundaye and holy daye, after the reading of the Gospell of the day, the Curate of euery parishe do make, (according to suche talent as God hath geuen hym) a godlye and briefe exhortation to hys Parishioners: mouing and exciting them to remembre the poore people, and the duetie of Christian charitie, in relieuing of them, whiche bee their brethren in Christe, borne in the same Parishe, & neding their helpe.

Prouided alwayes, that if it shal chaunce anye such adiudged apprentice, seruaunt, or slaue, as is before rehearsed, to haue inheritaunce descēded vnto him, or her, or any other wayes, by the lawes of thys realm̄, warde, or bondeman, or neife of bloude, by, or from anye of hys auncestoures, to any persone or persones: That then it shalbe lawfull to anye suche persone or persones, to whome anye suche warde, bonde man, or neife shall apperteigne, to sease and take suche wardes, bonde men, or neifes, and them to reteigne and kepe, as theyre wardes, bonde men, or neifes, And the sayde wardes, bonde men, and neifes shalbe discharged of the said slauery, or other seruitude, or bondage aboue rehersed: Thys estatute, or any thing therein conteined, to the contrary in any wise notwithstanding.

And also bee it enacted, that if anye suche seruaunt, apprentice, slaue, or slaues, whiche shall haue at any time hereafter any aduauncement or liuing, accrue, come, or growe vnto hym, or anye of them, whereby hee, or they may haue a conuenient liuing, that then, and from thenceforth, hee or they so being aduaunced, to be discharged of their slauery, seruitude, and bondage: thys Acte, or any thing therein conteined to the contrary in any wise notwithstanding. Any woman being a seruaūt, apprentice, or slaue, as is aforesaide, being maried within the age of xx. yeres, without the assent of her maister, vntill she shal accomplishe and come to the sayde age of xx. yeres, onely excepted.

Bee it also enacted, that all Leprouse, and poore beddered creatures, whatsoeuer they bee, may at theyr owne libertie remayne and continue in such houses appointed for leprouse, or beddred people, as they now be in, & shal not be compelled to repayre into any other coūtreys or places, by the vertue of thys acte: any thing therin cōteined to the cōtrary notwithstanding. And that also it shalbe lefull vnto the sayd Leprouse and beddred people, for theire better reliefes, to appointe their Proctor or Proctors, so there be not appointed aboue the number of two persons, for anye one house of Leprouse beddred people, to gather the charitable almose of all such inhabitauntes, as shalbee within the compasse of .iiii. myles of any of the sayde houses of leprous and beddred persons.

And be it ordeyned and enacted by the auctoritie abouesayde, that it
shalbe lawful to euery persone, to whom anye persone in fourme abouesayde, shalbe adiudged a slaue, to put a ring of yron about hys necke, arme, or hys legge, for a more knowlege and suertie of the keping of hym. And that if any persone or persones do take, or helpe to take anye suche bonde of yron from anye suche slaue, that then euerye persone so doinge without the licence or assent of hys maister, shall forfayte for euery suche defaute x. poundes sterling.

Be it further enacted, that thys present acte shall before the firste daye of Marche next comming, be openly proclaimed in euerye Citie, Corporate towne, and market Towne, vpon the market daye: and also from thenceforth shall yerely bee read in euery Shyre openly in two general quarter sessions of the peace, that is to say, at the general quarter sessiōs after Midsomer, and the general quarter sessiōs next after Christemas, to the intent that euery persone may haue knowledge thereof, and that thys acte shall endure vnto the ende of the next Parlament.

Prouided alwayes, & be it enacted, that it shalbe lawfull to the Lorde Chauncelour of England, or the Lord keper of the great Seale for the tyme being at theire discretions to graunt commission vnder the greate seale of Englande, to euery, or any persone or persones that hath, or shal haue hys or theire houses or barnes burnt, or suche losses, to gather the reliefe and charitie of others for theire ayde and helpe, of hys or theire losses, decay, or hinderaunce, as in time past hath been vsed: any thinge conteined in thys acte notwithstanding.

div.head: ¶ An acte for Tenures holden in Capite. ¶ The .iiii. Chapiter.
div.p:
WHere before this time, ambiguities, q̄stions, & doubts haue been moued & stirred in diuers & sundry ye kings courtes of Recorde, whether suche honours, castles, manours, landes, tenem̄ts, & other hereditam̄ts are holden of the kyng in Capite, whiche any hys louing subiectes doe holde by knightes seruice, Socage, or other seruices of the king, as of his Duchies, Erledomes, Baronies, honours, castles, manours, landes, tenements, fees, and seignouries, which haue come to the handes & possessiō of diuers of his hyghenes most noble progenitours, by atteindour of treason, misprision of treason, atteindours of Premunire, & prouision had & doen by acte of Parlamēt, by verdicte, cōfession, conuictiō, or vtlagarie, & offices or no offices thereupon founde, or by the dissolution, surrender, or geuing vp to the kyng, or to any hys noble Progenitours, of any religious or Ecclesiastical houses or places, or of anye Manoures, Landes, Tenementes, and other hereditaments, to anye of the same religious or Ecclesiastycal houses or places in anye wise appertaininge or belonging, or no: By meanes of whiche doubte so moued, hys sayde humble and obedient Subiectes and tenauntes haue been heretofore muche vnquieted,
molested, and greued: wherfore the kynge our souereigne Lorde, mynding, and entierlye desiring the quietnesse of hys sayde Subiectes, and that the certaintie of hys lawes in that behalfe myght bee knowen, and declared to hys sayde louing subiectes, for a plaine declaration and resolution to bee had, of, for, and concerning the premysses at the humble petition and suite of the Lordes and commons in thys present Parlamēt assembled, doth ordeyne, declare, and enacte by the assent of the Lordes Spiritual and temporal, and of the commons in this present Parlamēt assembled, and by the aucthoritie of the same, that all suche Honoures, Castles, Manours, Landes, Tenementes, and other hereditamentes, and euerye of them, whiche nowe bee, or at anye tyme hereafter shalbe holden of the kyng, or of any of hys heires or successours, by anye of hys sayde Subiectes, by knyghtes seruice, Socage, or otherwise, as of any of his or their Dukedomes, Earledomes, Baronies, Castles, manours, Landes, Tenementes, Fees, or Seignories, whiche bee come to the Kynge, or hys moste noble progenitoures, or hereafter shall come to the Kyng, hys heyres or successours, by meanes of any suche Attainder, conuiction, vtlagarie, or of any suche dissolution, surrendre, or geuing vp of anye Religious or Ecclesiastical houses or places, or of any Manours, landes, tenementes, or hereditamentes, to anye of the sayd religious or Ecclesiasticall houses or places in anye wise belonging or apperteining, shall not from henceforth bee adiudged, deemed, taken or construed to any intent, cōstruction or purpose, to be holden in Capite, or as Tenure in Capite: anye ambignitie, question, or doubte heretofore moued to the contrary notwithstanding.

Prouided alwayes, and be it enacted by the auctoritie aforesayd, that thys act or any thing therin conteyned, shall not in any wise be preiudiciall ne hurteful to the kynge, hys heires or successours, to, for, or concerning any wardeship, liuery, primer season, fine for alienation, or to, or for any other profite or aduauntage, whiche now is come, or hereafter shal, or maye come, fall, or growe to the kyng, hys heyres, or successoures, by or from any persone or persones, whiche now doth, or hereafter shal holde any honours, seigniouries, castles, manours, landes, tenementes, or other hereditaments of the kyng in Chiefe, as of hys persone, or of any other hys auncient possessions, and being not come to the kyng by anye suche attainder, confession, conuiction, vtlagarie, dissolution, geuing vp, or surrender, as bee abouesayde.

Prouided alwayes, & be it enacted by the aucthoritie aforesayde, that thys present act, or any thing therein conteined, or specified, shall not in anye wyse, or by anye meanes, geue anye aduauntage, libertie, or profit to anye Tenaunt or owner in Fee simple, of anye Honours, Manours, Landes, tenementes, or other hereditamentes, whiche haue heretofore sued anye special or general liuerie, or ouster le mayne, out of the handes of the kynge, or of anye hys noble Progenitours, of anye Honours,
manours, landes, tenementes, or other hereditamentes, by what tenor or seruice they were, or be holden, or that haue, or shall confesse by anye mater of record, any tenor in chiefe of the king, but that they, their heirs and assignes shall haue and holde the same manours, landes, tenementes, and other hereditaments, in like maner and fourme, as they did before the making of thys present Act, & as though thys present Acte had neuer been had, ne made: any thing aboue declared and enacted to the contrarye notwithstanding.

div.head: ¶ An Acte that no horses shalbe conueighed out of thys Realme, and other the kynges dominions without licence. ¶ The .vi. Chapiter.
div.p:
WHere before thys tyme, diuers of the kynges Subiectes, and namely of the North partes of thys Realme, aswel in time of peace as of warre, haue conueighed, sold, geuē, & deliuered out of thys realme, aswel into Stotland, as into other forein realmes, beyonde the Sea, many & diuers greate multitude of horses, geldings and mares, whiche haue been thought, aswell great occasion, strength & boldnesse to the Scottishmen, & other ye kings forein enemes, hauing in possession the same horses, geldings, & mares, in time of warre to inuade this realm̄, as also a great decay of the good breede of horses and mares, whiche before tyme hath been within thys realme, to the great detriment & hinderaūce of the kynges poore subiectes towardes the defence of thys realme and other hys deminions. For remedy wherof: be it therfore enacted by our souereigne lord the kyng, & by the commons in thys present parlament assembled, & by the auctoritie of the same, that yf anye persone or persones, after the firste daye of Ianuary next comming, doe sell, exchaūge, geue, conueigh, or deliuer into the realme of Scotland, to the vse of any Scottisheman, or do carye, geue, exchaunge, sell, send, conueigh, or deliuer into anye place beyond ye sea out of thys realme, or the dominions of the same, any horse, gelding, or mare, without special licence therefore to bee obteined of the kynges highnes, or of hys heires, vnder the great seale of thys realme, or vnder the priuie signate: or if anye persone or persones, after the firste daye of Ianuary, do sell, exchaūge, geue, or deliuer to any Scottishman within this realme of England, or Wales, the townes of Berwike, or the marches of the same, to thintent to be conueighed into Scotland, any horse, gelding, or mare, or do conueighe, or cary any horse, mare, or gelding into any forein parties beyond the sea, without like special licēce obteined of the kynges hyghnesse, or of hys heires, vnder the great seale, or priuie signate as is aforesayde: that then the same person and persons so offending contrary to thys acte, shal lose and forfeyte to our souereigne lorde and hys heyres, the same horse, mare, or geldyng, so caried and conueyghed, and shall also lose and forfayte the summe of fourtie poundes for
euery such horse, geldyng, or mare, so to be cōueighed & caried in forme aforesaid: whereof the one moitie to bee to the kyng, & the other moitie to hym, or thē, that will sue for the same, by information, action of debte, or detinue in any of the kynges courtes of Recorde, in whiche suite, no wager of lawe, essoine, ne protection shalbe allowed. And that also all & euery persone and persones so offending, contrary to thys act, shal suffre imprisonement by the space of one whole yere.

And be it further enacted by the aucthoritie aforesayde, that it shalbe leful, aswell to the warden & wardens of the East, west, & middle marches, for the time being, in their warden courtes, as also to all and euery the kynges Iustices of Peace in euery shyre, aswell in Englande, as in Wales, in theire quarter sessions, to enquire of all and euerye offence or offences hereafter to be perpetrated, committed, or doen cōtrary to this act: And that it shalbe lefull to all and euery persone & persons being the kynges subiectes, to arrest & vnprison euery Scottishman, & all & euery other persone, or persones, whiche shall leade, or conueyghe contrarye to the meaning of thys Acte, any suche horse, geldyng, or mare, out of thys realme into the said realme of Scotland, or into any other foreine place beyond the sea, other then such persons, as hereafter shall haue sufficient warraunt, by, or from the kynges hyghnesse or hys heires, vnder hys, or their great seale, or priuie signate, according to the meaning of thys act.

Prouided alwayes, & be it enacted by the aucthoritie aforesayde, that yf the kyng our soueraigne Lord, hys heires or successours, at any tyme hereafter, vnder his great seale, or priuie signate, doe geue licence to any persone or persones, to cary or conueigh any horses, mares, or geldings, into Stotland, or into any other parte beyond the Sea, or els doe geue aucthoritie, power, or commaundement to anye persone or persones, by warraunt, vnder the kynges great Seale, to licence any other person or persones to carye, or conueighe anye Horses, Mares, or geldynges into Scotlande, or into any parties beyond the sea, that then it shalbe lefull, aswell to all and singular person & persons hauing suche licence vnder ye kyngs great seale, or priuie signate, as to all and euery other person, and persons, hauing licence in writtinge vnder the seale of suche persone, or persones, to whom the kynge shall geue auctoritie, power, or commaundement in fourme abouesaid, to licēce other person or persons to cary or conueigh any horses, mares, or geldynges into Scotlande, or into anye parties beyond the sea, to cary & cōueigh such nūbre of horses, geldings or mares, or any of them into Scotlād, or into any of the parties beyōd the sea, as shalbe mētioned in any such licence, as is before specified anye thing mētioned in thys act, to ye cōtrary in any wise notwithstanding.

Prouided alwayes, and be it enacted by the auctoritie aforesayd, that thys act, ne any thing therein conteined, shal in any wise extende, to any persone or persones, which at any time hereafter shall cary or conueighe any horse, Mare, or gelding into Scotlande, or into anye other foreine
parties beyonde the sea, to serue the kyng in hys warres, with the same horses, Mares, or geldinges, anye thinge mencioned in thys acte, to the contrary in any wise notwithstanding.

And to the intent the kynges Maiestie shal not hereafter be deceiued in the numbre of suche horses, mares, or geldinges, which hereafter shalbe caried and conueighed into Scotlande, ne that the parties, whiche hereafter shal obtaine any licence by force of thys act, for the cariage or conueighaunce of any horses, mares, or geldynges, to bee caried or conueyghed into Scotlande: Bee it therfore enacted by aucthoritie aforesaide, that all and euery such persone & persones, which hereafter shalbe licenced according to thys acte, to carie or conueigh any horses, mares, or geldynges into Scotlande, shall before the same cariage, or conueyghaunce, vpon the peyne of forfeyture of the said horse, mare, or gelding or the double value thereof: whereof the one moitie to be to the kyng, & the other moitie to him, or them that will sue for the same by suche like action, as before is limitted in thys acte, shewe hys or their said licence, to one of the three wardens of the three marches of Englande, to thintent that one of the said wardens shal cause the number of the said horses, mares, or geldynges so lycenced to bee conueighed into Scotlande, not onely to be kalēdard in a booke, to remaine in hys own custody: but also to be endorced and written on the backeside of the saide licence, and the same endorsement to be signed with the hande of the sayde warden.

Prouided alwayes, that it shalbe lefull to euerye of the kynges Subiectes, that shall passe ouer beyond the sea, to shyp and carye with them, horses, or geldynges, for theyr owne occupation in their iourneyes, and not to the intent to sell the same beyond the sea: And that intente to bee iudged by the othe of hym, or them, that so will cary ouer anye horse, or gelding, whiche othe shalbe taken before the Customers, or their deputies, or searcher of euery such Porte, where the same horse, or geldinge shalbe shipped before the shipping thereof.

Prouided alwayes, that the warden of the fiue portes now being, or hereafter to be, may yerely at his pleasure, geue six horses, or geldings, & no more, within one yere, at one, or diuers tymes, vpon like peine as is aforesaid, to any persone or persones, in the parties beyonde the seas, being in amitie with the kynges highnesse, or his successours: thys acte or any thing therein, to the contrary notwithstanding.

Prouided also, that this acte, nor any thing therein mencioned, bee in any wise hurtful or preiudicial to the maister of the kynges horses, now & hereafter to be, for such thinges & cōmodities, as shall & doe concerne his office, any thing in thys acte to the contrary notwithstanding.

Prouided also, that it shalbe lefull to anye the kynges Subiectes, to cary, or sende into any partes beyond the sea, anye mares, whereof the price of any one mare so to be caried, doth not exceade .x.s. in suche and lyke maner, as Mares beynge of the price of vi.s. viii.d. haue beene, or
might haue been conueighed ouer the Seas, before the makyng of this acte: any thing in thys act, or in any other act or actes heretofore made to the contrary hereof notwithstanding.

div.head: ¶ An Acte for the continuaunce of makyng of wolsted yarne in Norffolke. ¶ The .vi. Chapiter.
div.p:
WHere the greatest, & almost the whole numbre of the poore inhabitaunts of the countie of Norffolke, & the citie of Norwiche, be, and haue been heretofore for a great time mainteined, & gotten theire liuing by spinning of the wolles growing in ye said countie of Norfolke vpon the rock into yarne, & by all the saide time haue vsed to haue their accesse to common markettes within the said coūtie and citie, to buye theire wolles there to be spūne as is aforesaide, of certaine persones called retailers of the same wolles be eight peny worth, and twelue peniworth at one tyme or thereabout, and haue not vsed to buye, ne can buye theire saide wolle of the breders of the same wolles by such small parcelles, aswell for that the sayde breders of the sayde wolles will not sell their said wolles by such small parcelles, as also for that the most parte of the sayde poore persones dwell farre of from the said breders of the said wolles: And forasmuche as by an acte of Parlament made in the xxxvii. yere of the reigne of the noble king of famous memorie Henry the viii. all persones be restreigned vpō a great paine, to bye any wolles to sell ye same againe, except merchaūts of the Staple, for the onely prouision of the Staple, as in the sayd acte emong other thinges more at large it is conteined: therfore the said retailers of wolles in the said countie of Norfolke and citie of Norwiche, whiche heretofore haue vsed to buye wolles, and to sell them agayn to the saide poore persones in ouert markettes as is aforesayd, haue synce the makyng of the said estatut in eschewing the daunger and peyne prouided by the same, ceassed and left to bye the sayd wolles, for the reliefe of the sayde poore persones: By reason wherof, the same poore persones inhabiting within the saide countie of Norffolke and citie of Norwich, that hath heretofore been spinners, and mainteined by spinninge of the sayde wolles, be now vnoccupied and vnset a worke, and a great numbre of them inforced to begge for lacke of worke, to the vtter decay and ruyne of the poore people of the said Countie and Citie, and the inhabitauntes thereof, vnlesse some remedy be therin prouided. In consideracion whereof, it may please the kyngs most royal maiestie, by the assent of the lordes spiritual & temporal, & the commons in thys present parlament assembled, and by auctoritie of the same, that all and euery person and persones dwelling and inhabiting within the saide countie of Norfolke and citie of Norwiche, or in eyther of them, by his, or thē selfes, or
by his, or their factours, seruaunt or seruauntes may lawfully frō hensforth without peine, forfaiture, daungier, or breache of anye lawe or ordinaunce, to buie and bargain wolles, and take and make prouision to buie or bargain wolles growing, or that shal grow only within the said coūtie of Norfolke, in as large and like maner and fourme as the same inhabitauntes within the sayde coūtie and Citie might, & did vse to do before the making of the saide acte of Parlament, & as the sayde acte of Parlament had neuer been had or made, so that the same person and {per}sons so buiynge or barganing, or makinge promise to buye or bargaine the saied wolles, do sell or retaile the same againe in the common market, or other open place within the saide countie of Norfolke, or Citie of Norwiche, to any persone or persones at their pleasure and libertie that will bie the same, or any parcel therof, dwelling and inhabiting within the saide countie and citie of Norwiche, or any of them, that shall or will spinne the same within the saide countie of Norfolke, and Citie of Norwiche, or any of them: the sayd former acte, or any article, clause or sentence therein contained, or any other acte or actes, lawe, or ordinaunce heretofore made, to the contrarie thereof in anye wise notwithstāding.

And where in the Parlamēt holden at westminster the xxxiii. yere of the reigne of our saide late Souereine Lord the Kyng, it was amongst other thinges enacted thus, as ensueth, or like in effect, that is to saye, that no persone or persones from hensefoorth, shoulde buye, ne cause to bee boughte within the sayde Citye of Norwiche, or Countie of Norfolke, anye yarne spunne of the rocke, called wolsted yarne, the whiche shoulde then after that bee spunne within the sayde Countye or Citie, but suche person or persons beinge weuers of woolsted, Russels, Stamine, Saies, and suche other like Clothes, within the saide Citye or Countie, that shoulde weue or worke, or cause to be wouen or wrought in woolsted, Stamine, Russelles, Saies, or suche other like clothes, the sayde yarne so bought, or caused to bee bought within the sayde Citye or Countie, in the Citie of Norwiche, or in some market towne within the sayde Countie: vpon the peine and forfeiture for euerye pounde weight of the said yarne called wolsted yarne, so bought within the said Countie or Citie, and not wouen or wrought, as is aforesayde, within the sayde Citie or countie, fourtie shillinges, the one halfe therof to be to the king our souereigne Lord, and the other halfe thereof to be to hym, or them that shoulde then after that sue for the same by byll, informaciō, action of dette, or otherwise in anye courte of Recorde, in whiche sayde action, bill, or information, no essoine, wager of law, foreine plee, or protection shoulde bee allowed. And where it is also ordeined in the sayde acte, that yf anye persone or persones, did after the first day of April thē next after the said acte ensuing, ship, or carie, or conueigh, or cause to bee shipped, to carie, or conueigh into the parties beyond the Sea, or did cary or conueigh into the partes beyond the sea, any yarne called woolsted
yarn not made, or wrought in cloth, so that such yarn were spūne with in thys Realme, that then euery person & persones so shipping, cōueighing, and carying, or causing such yarne so to be shipped, caried, and conueighed should forfayt for euery pounde of woolsted yarne so shypped, conueighed, or caried .xl.s. the one halfe thereof to be to our saide Soueraigne Lorde the kyng, & the other halfe therof to him, or them that should sue for the same, by bill, informacion, or accion of debte in any of the kyngs courts of Record, as in the said acte the same, or the lyke in effect, more plainely dooth & may appeare. And forasmuche as the sayd acte was made & ordeined to continue & endure vntil the Parliament then after that next ensuing, & hath been sithens by other general actes continued vntill this present Parliament, & was not by any of the said actes ordeined to continue for euer: It may now please the kings most excellent maiesty, with thassent of the Lordes Spirituall & temporall, & the commons in this present Parliament assembled, & by aucthoritye of the same, that all the afore resited acte for yarne, with al the words, forfaitures, paines, & sentences before recited, as the same before recited and declared, may from henceforth be enacted to continue, & to bee taken for an acte to cōtinue for euer to al intents & purposes, according to ye said words, sētences, & the purport therof before in this act recited

Prouided alwaies that it shalbe leful to euery person & persones, being a hatte maker, or hat makers, dwelling within ye said citye of Norwiche, to buy such of the sayd woolsted yarne, as is called and knowen by the name of middle vffe yarne, as they and euery of them haue heretofore done, & vsed to doe, so that the same middle vffe yarne so bought by the said hatmakers, or hatmaker, be wrought in hattes, or emploied to hatmaking within the saide citie, any thing before recited, to the cōtrary thereof notwithstanding.

div.head: ¶ The .vii. Chapiter. ¶ An Acte for the continuance of Actions after the death of any king.
div.p:
WHere the Kynges subiectes heretofore haue to theire greate costes, charges, and expences, prosecuted, and sued dyuerse and sundrye Actions, aswell reall and personall, as all other Actions mixte, or otherwyse, in the kynges Maiestyes courts and other courtes of recorde, not onelye by wryttes, but also by plaint or bylles, whiche actions, suites, bylles, and plaintes, by the deathe, or demyse of the Kynges of this Realme, haue been dyscontinued, and the parties in euery suche accions, suites, billes, & playntes, therby haue been put without day, wherby the demaundaunts, playntifes, and actours in euery suche action and suite were compelled and driuen by the order of the lawes of this realme, for their further remedy, to cōmence & begin again his, or their saide actions, suites, or plaints, or els to prosecute, & sue resommons, attachements, Scire facias, or suche other like,
processe to reuiue his or their said actions, sutes, or plaints, which was not onelye to their great costes, charges, expences, hinderaunces, & delay of theire causes & suites, but also a greate lette and hynderaunce of iustice, for reformacion wherof, be it ordeined, established, & enacted by the king our souereigne Lorde, & the Lordes & commons in thys present parliament assembled, and by the aucthorytye of the same, that frō henceforth by the death, or demise of the kings Maiestie that now is, (whose life almightie God long preserue, kepe & maintain in his moste royal estate) nor by the death or demise of any yt hereafter shalbe kinge of this Realme, any accion, suite, bill, or plaint, nowe, or that hereafter shall depende betwene party and party in any of the courtes aforesaid shal not in any wise be discontynued, or put without day: But that the processe, plees, demurres, and continuaunces in euerye action, actyons, suites, bylles, or plaintes, whiche nowe, or that hereafter shal depende shall stand good and effectual, and be prosecuted, & sued forthe in suche maner & fourme, & in the same estate, cōdicion and order, as if the same king had liued, or continued in full life, the deathe or demise hereafter of any king of this Realme notwithstandyng. And that all & all maner of iudicial processe that hereafter shalbe had, or pursued in the time of ye reigne of any other king, then reigned at the time of the pursuite of the original, or other former processe, shalbe made in the name of the kyng, that for the time shall reigne, and be king of this realme, and that variaunce touching the same processe betwene the names of the kings, shal not be in any wise material, as concerning any defaulte to bee alleged, or obiected therefore.

And also be it further established and enacted by thaucthority aforesaid yt al & euery Assise of nouel disseisin, assise of mortdauncestour, Iuris vtrum, & atteint, which at any time hereafter shalbe arreygned, cōmenced or sued before any of the kings Iustices of assise, shal not from hēceforth be discontinued or put without day, by reason of death, new commission, associacion, or not cōming of the same Iustices of assise, or anye of them, but shal stand good & effectual in the lawe, to all intents, constructions and purposes, the death, new commission associacion, or not cōming of the same Iustices, or any of thē, in any wise notwithstāding.

And ouer that, be it ordeined & enacted by the aucthority aforesaide, that albeit any demaundaunt or plaintife in any maner of accion, byll, or suite, shall fortune to bee made, or created Duke, Archebishop, Marques, Earle, Viscount, Baron, Bishop, Knight, Iustice of the one bēch, or of the other, or Sergeaunt at lawe, depending the same accion, bill, or suite, yet that notwithstanding, that no writ, action, or suite, shall for such cause in anye wise bee abatable or abated, but shal remaine in like force, goodnes, & strength, as the same was before, anye lawe, or vsage to the contrary in any wise notwithstanding.

And also be it ordeined and enacted by the aucthoritie aforesaid, that
albeit any person, or persons beyng Iustice of assyse, Iustyce of Gaole delyuery: or Iustice of peace within any of the kings dominions, or being in any other of the kings commissions whatsoeuer, shall fortune to be made, or created Duke, Archebishop, Marques, Earle, Viscoūt, baron, Bishop, Knight, Iustyce of thone benche, or of the other, or sergeāt at law, or sheryf, yet that notwithstāding, he, & they shal remain iustyce & cōmissioner, & haue ful power & auctoritie to execute the same, in like maner & forme, as he, or they might, or ought to haue dō before ye same.

And be it ordeined & enacted by the aucthoritie aforesaide, that in al cases, where any persone, or persones heretofore haue ben, or hereafter shalbe found gilty of any maner of treason, murder, manslaughter, rape or other felony whatsoeuer, for the which iudgement of death should, or may ēsue, & shalbe repried to prison without iudgement at that time geuen agaynst him, her, or them so found gilty, that those persons that at any time hereafter shal by the kinges letters Patentes bee assigned Iustices to deliuer the Gaole, where any such person or persons found giltie shall remaine, shal haue ful power and aucthoritie to geue iudgement of death against such person so founde gilty, and repried, as thesame iustices (before whom suche person or persons was, or were foūd gilty) might haue done, if their cōmission of Gaole deliuery had remained & contynued in full force & strength. And ouer that, that no maner of processe, or suit made, sued, or had before any Iustyces of Assise, gaole delyuery, Oyer and terminer, iustice of peace, or other of the Kynges cōmissyoners, shal, ne in any wise be discontinued by the making & publishing of any new commission or associaciō, or bee altering of ye names of ye iustices of assise, gaole deliuery, Oyer and terminer, iustices of peace or other the kings commissioners, but that the newe iustices of assise, Gaole deliuery, and of the peace, & other cōmissioners maye procede in euerye behalfe, as if the olde commissions, and Iustices, & commyssyoners had styll remained & continued not altered.

div.head: ¶ The viii. Chapiter. ¶ An Acte for the confirmacion of letters Patentes.
div.p:
WHere the Kinges most excellent highnesse sithen the .xxviii. day of Ianuarie, in the firste yeare of hys Maiestyes reygne, aswell vpon dyuerse and sundry good consideracions, hys Maiestye specyallye mouyng, as also otherwyse, hathe bargayned, solde, exchaunged, geuen, restored, and graunted by hys graces seuerall letters Patentes, indentures, or other wrytynges sealed vnder hys hyghnesse greate Seale of Englande, the Seale of hys Duchie of Lancaster, and the seale of the Courte of Augmentacion, & the Reuenues of his crowne, or any of them, as wel to bodies politique & corporate, as to diuers and sundry of his louing and obediēt subiects, diuerse and sundrye honours, castelles, maners, landes, tenementes, rentes, reuercions, seruices, personages appropriated, aduowsons,
tithes, oblacyons, pencions, porcyons, fraunchises, priuileges, liberties & other hereditaments, commodityes & profites in fee simple, fee tayle, for terme of life, or lyues, or for terme of yeares, as in ye same seueral letters patents, Indentures, & other writings is mencyoned & declared: In auoiding, disturbing, hurting, or hindering of the saide seuerall letters patentes, Indentures, and other writinges, and of the saide mannors, landes, tenementes, hereditamentes, and other thynges in them conteined, sundry and manye ambiguities, doubtes, & questions haue or myght hereafter happē to be moued, obiected, alleged, inuented, procured, or sterred, aswel for misnaming, misrecital, or none recital of any of the same Honours, castelles, manours, landes, tenements, and other the premisses, or any parcell therof, or for lacke of fyndyng of offyces, or inquisicions, of, and in the premisses, whereby the tytle of the Kynges highnes therin ought to haue been found before the makyng of ye same letters patentes, or other writynge, or for misrecitall, or none recital of lesses therof before made, aswel of recorde as not of recorde, or for lack of the certeintye, miscasting, rating, or setting forth of the yerely values and rates of the premisses, or of the yerely rents reserued, of, and for the premisses, or any parcell therof mencioned, or conteyned in any of ye said letters patentes, or other writings, or for that the premysses bee, or any part thereof is valued to a more, or lesse value in the said letters patentes, or wrytings, then the saide honours, manours, lands, tenemēts and other the premisses then were or shalbe in yerely value, or for mysnaming of the townes, hamlettes, parishes, or counties, where ye same honours, castelles, manbrs, landes, tenementes, rentes, hereditaments and other the premisses, and euery parcel therof, or anye parcell thereof lien, or beene, or for lacke of the true naminge of the natures, kyndes, sortes, and quantities of the saide possessions, or hereditamentes, or anye parcel thereof, or for lacke of the true naming of the corporacion of the same bodies politique, or corporate, or for lacke of attornement, lyuerie, or season, or for misnaming of any of the late tenants, or fermors of the same premisses so solde, geuen, graunted, or exchaūged, as for diuerse and sundrie other suggestions and surmises, not comprised in the said letters patentes, which hereafter might happen to be moued, surmised, or procured against the same letters patents. For remedye & reformacion wherof be it ordeined and enacted by the kinges most excellent highnesse, with thassent of the Lordes Spirituall & temporal, & ye cōmons in this present parliament assembled, & by thaucthoritye of the same, that aswel al & euery the saide letters patēts, indentures, & other wrytings, & euery of thē sealed with, or vnder the seale or seales aboue named, or any of them made, or graunted by the kings highnes sithens the .xxviii. day of Ianuary last past, as also al and synguler hys graces letters patents, indentures, and other writings hereafter, during hys highnesse life (which our Lord long continue) to be had, made, or graūted
